BATAVIA, Java., Oct. 18 (AP)-- The Indonesian nationalists today demanded absolute independence from the Netherlands, asserting the alternative was "war or revolution."

Naming the budget plan as one of the primary factors in efficient home making, Miss Eleanor T. Lurry, superintendent of home economics for the Department of Welfare, made public last night financial schedules for families of two and three persons for the benefit of war widows and their offspring.
BERLIN, Oct. 18--An indictment returned today before the International Tribunal holds the Germans responsible for the slaughter of 11,000 Polish officers in the Katyn forest near Smolensk.
An SOS from service women for wardrobe help in going "back to civvies" was answered yesterday in a two-part fashion showing at the Women's Military Services Club at 451 Madison Avenue.

A jockey stole the show at the Jamaica race track yesterday. Teddy Atkinson, long considered among the top-flight rides in the country, added to his reputation when he rode home five winners on the seven-race card.

PARIS, Oct. 29--Despite criticism and what the French press has been freely interpreting as threats originating in Allied circles in Berlin, the French tonight are standing pat on their refusal to accept the proposals for unified control in Germany.
Some grocers may think selfservice supermarkets suitable only for low and medium-income neighborhoods, but not Patsy D'Agostino, chairman of the Greater New York Retail Grocers Conference.

TOKYO, Oct. 19 (AP)--Japan's liberated Communist minority-- long imprisoned for its radical views--sought the help of its former foe, the Socialists, today for the bitter fight it proposed against Premier Kijuro Shidehara's new Government.

J.J. Donovan, formerly New York regional manager of Airtemp division, Chrysler Corporation, has been appointed Eastern divisional manager for the company. Robert Friedel moves up to succeed Mr. Donovan.

The Port of New York resumed work at a feverish pace yesterday as the government and shipping concerns attempted to retrieve lost time and get out the ships that had been strike-bound for nearly three weeks.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (AP)--The board of directors of the Illinois Central Railroad Company today authorized a call for tenders of certain bonds maturing in 1950-5152, with the company reserving the right to accept such bonds as are tendered at satisfactory prices. Included in the call are bonds outstanding in the amount of approximately $54,000,000 par value.

Flashing a diversified attack, Horace Mann's football team vanquished St. Paul's School of Garden City, L.I., by a 27-6 score yesterday on the winner's gridiron. In recording its second triumph in three times out, the Maroon and White tallied in each period, with Allen Ackerman and Sam Messiter setting a fast pace.
B. Brewster Jennings, president of Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, addressed the twenty-fifth anniversary dinner of the company's Twenty-Year Club last night at Hotel Astor. More than 1,200 attended.

At the request of Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, the Board of Education's advisory committee on human relations is to be reorganized, with new members added, Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University, announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19-- George S. Munson, counsel for a committee of preferred stockholders of the Commonwealth Southern Corporation, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today during an oral argument that delay in carrying out the corporation's recapitalization plan had resulted in a "speculators' heyday" on the securities market.

Pfc. Herbert J. Rosencrans, Company C, 415th Infantry, 104th Division, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin J. Rosencrans of Woodmere, L.I., who died of wounds last Feb. 25 in Arnoldsweiler, Germany, has received posthumously the Silver Star Medal, it was announced yesterday.
A notable achievement in wartime usefulness has been reported to the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross by its chairman, Colby M. Chester.

The washing machine, the stair carpet, the bathtub, the family medicine chest and dozens of other household standbys may cause serious injury or death if proper care, is not taken, according to a "booby trap" questionnaire that will soon come into every New York home which has children at school.

The U.S.S. New York, first battleship to enter this port for the Navy Day review next Saturday, docked at the foot of Jane Street yesterday. She came in alone.

JEFFERSON, Wis., Oct. 19-- George Grimm, former circuit judge who retired in 1937 after forty years on the bench, died here yesterday. His age was 84.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz may become a key witness in the ArmyNavy controversy before the Senate Military Affairs Committee on the proposal for unification of the Army, Navy and Air Forces.

Municipal bonds up for sale next week aggregate $38,875,000, as compared with only $5,762,040 the past week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The weekly average of offerings for the year to date is $22,423,788.

William O'Dwyer, DemocraticAmerican Labor party candidate for Mayor, urged last night the establishment of a city-wide tribunal as a clinic for wayward youngsters rather than their appearance in a criminal court. The candidate addressed a large audience at a rally under the auspices of the American-Irish Committee in Manhattan Center.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 19 --The impending visit of Mark Ethridge, State Department special observer, is the main topic of interest in Rumanian political circles and some effort is apparently being made to prepare for it, as is shown by the removal of Russian censorship on American and British dispatches.

Twenty-four Nazi leaders stand charged in the indictment handed up this week to the International Military Tribunal. At the same time the prosecutors are seeking to establish once and for all the criminal character of the agencies which these men organized and led.

ALBANY, Oct. 19 (AP)--Bobsledders, "grounded" by the war, will get their first crack in three years this season at the Mount Van Hoevenberg Olympic run at Lake Placid. The North American and National Amateur Athletic Union championships will be held on the course early next year.

HANOI, French Indo-China, Oct. 16 (Delayed) (U.P.)-- Nationalist Premier and Foreign Minister Hu Chieh-ming charged today that French forces landed from the sea attacked Annamites today at Hongai, thirty-five miles east of Haiphong, on the northeast IndoChina coast.

Reuther, union vice president, beginning what he called a chapterand-verse justification of a demand for a 30 per cent wage increase.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)-- Georgia Tech's football players took in the capital's sights today, but they have no illusions about taking in Navy's great team in Baltimore tomorrow night.

Phelps, chief of the State Department division of Foreign Economic Development, are slated for appointment in the near future as the American representatives on the European reparations commission.

Undefeated Columbia will risk its string of three football victories against formidable Colgate at Baker Field today in a contest abounding in dire possibilities for the Lions if they happen to fall short of the heights attained last Saturday against Yale. The kickoff is scheduled for 2:30 P.M.

Tomorrow being "Annual Laymen's Sunday" throughout the country, many Manhattan churches will have laymen in their pulpits to preach. Robert G. Le Tourneau, industrialist, of Vicksburg, Miss., will preach in two churches.

The battleship New York, sixth of her name, arrived here yesterday, thirty-one months and four battles out of home port. It was her last homeward run. In a matter of weeks the New York will be given over to the cutter's torch or sacrificed in research to a test of the atomic bomb.

Defeat caught up with Mrs. Laudy Lawrence's promising 2year-old filly, La Liberte, at Jamaica yesterday. The Californiabred speedster, who had scored easily and impressively in her two previous starts, had to be content with second place behind the Belair Stud's Bonnie Beryl in the featured Frizette Stakes, a new event with $10,000 added.

DENVER, Oct. 19 (AP)--Captured while smoking a cigarette beside his wife's body, a discharged soldier was held without charge today in the slaying which, police were told, was preceded and followed by his attacking a chance acquaintance.

Art Brady, Norbert Dinehardt, Jake Montovi and Earl Tompkins, all residents of the Lake Mahopac area, went hunting yesterday in the woodlands near their homes. What made the trip noteworthy was that each of them bagged a pheasant, something that a lot of other sportsmen have failed to do this week. The party saw seven birds altogether, but three of them were described by Brady as "impossible shots."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--Archibald MacLeish, former Assistant Secretary of State and former librarian of Congress, was appointed today chairman of the American Delegation to the Conference in London on Nov. 1 which will draw up the final continuation of the Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--The Senate Finance Committee, completing its decisions on reconversion-period tax reductions, voted today to grant $2,648,000,000 of relief to individuals, releasing an estimated 12,060,000 from tax rolls entirely in 1946, and to give cuts of $2,841,000,000 to business, with special treatment to concerns of net incomes under 60,000.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 19 (AP)--Responding to urging in the stretch, Mrs. A. Preece's Equanimous made it two straight over this track today when he defeated the Sandy Lane Farm's Elmo T. by a head. Five lengths behind the close finish for first money came L.G. Lefavire's Hadawin, the favorite, to be third in the field of five.

The case of the City versus Ettie Thomas Schacht involving the day care of children took a new turn in Brooklyn yesterday as Magistrate Thomas Cullen issued warrants for the arrest of Mrs. Schacht and an associate, Mrs. Corinne Wing.
Directors of the Erie Railroad yesterday declared the usual semiannual dividend of 50 cents a share, payable Dec. 15. Similar dividends have been distributed since 1942.

BATAVIA, Java, Oct. 19 (AP)-- British Gurkha troops occupied Semarang, on the north coast of Java, today after a three-hour skirmish in which two Gurkhas were killed and four wounded, a Netherlands News Agency dispatch said.

To the stranger seeing New York for the first time the amazing thing is that there should be a park in that incredibly busy area at all. New Yorkers, always on the run and too often forgetful of their near-by blessings, may pass it by as no part of their urgent business.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Oct. 19--A "completely satisfactory solution" of the problem of the treatment of German prisoners of war turned over to the French by the United States Army has been reached, Lieut. Gen. Walter B. Smith, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's Chief of Staff, announced today.

State Senator Lazarus Joseph, Democratic and American Labor party candidate for Controller, said yesterday that he might establish an office in Albany to see that New York City got back from the State a fair share of taxes paid by the city.

A selection of water colors and drawings by Jerome Myers may be seen at the Jerome Myers Gallery in Carnegie Hall where the work of the late artist is shown exclusively. The exhibition is open Tuesdays through Sundays from 2 to 6 o'clock.

PEIPING, Oct. 18 (U.P.) (delayed) --Chinese Communist Eighth Route Army posters and handbills in the Peiping area today accused United States forces of "interfering in Chinese internal politics" by garrisoning some cities and flying Chinese Government troops to garrison others.

A dispatch from our correspondent, Drew Middleton, calls attention to the plight of still another class of uprooted persons in Europe--the approximately 130,000 Lithuanians, Latvians and Estonians in the American, British and French zones in Germany.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--The Office of Price Administration removed from price control today a number of consumer items and industrial products "that do not enter significantly into the cent of living or business costs." The agency pointed out that, in all cases, the difficulty of maintaining control was disproportionate to the advantages of control.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)-- The Labor Department urged today the repeal of the strike-notice section of the War Labor Disputes Act. The department said this section was "hurting rather than helping the cause of industrial peace."

New York City's Third Annual Outdoor Chrysanthemum Display, the largest and most spectacular mass planting of these flowers in the country, is now in full bloom with 2,000,000 blossoms on view in five park areas, the Department of Parks announced yesterday.

The first of a series of six lecture-concerts entitled "This Is Our Music" was given at Town Hall yesterday afternoon under the general direction of Walter Hendl, the young American pianist and composer.

Buoyed by two honorably discharged soldiers of pre-war football vintage, pointless and victoryless New York University meets City College on Ohio Field, in the Bronx, at 2:30 P.M. today. The Beavers likewise are in quest of their first triumph.

When Steve Owen's football Giants come out on the Polo Grounds tomorrow afternoon to tangle for the second time this year with the Pittsburgh Steelers, there will be a new blocking quarterback in the Mara forces' starting line-up.

TOKYO, Oct. 19--Two separate political groups are preparing to consider revisions of the Japanese Constitution in line with the Allied demands for its liberalization, Foreign Minister Shigeru Yoshida said today in his first foreign press conference.

DETROIT, Oct. 19--K.T. Keller, president of the Chrysler Corporation, said today that he expected the country to work itself out of the present "confused" labor suituation, just as it did out of prohibition. Although he conceded that labor relations in Detroit were "not improving," he said they were not "hopeless; nothing in America is hopeless."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--President Truman's promised statement on wage-price policy, which was due today, was put off until Monday, it was announced by the White House Secretary, Charles G. Ross.

The National Foreign Trade Council called upon the United States to condition the extension of financial aid to Great Britain or to any other country with they effective removal of discriminations and restrictions against American foreign trade, in a statement released yesterday by Eugene P. Thomas, president.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--President Truman transferred the responsibility for disposal of consumer goods from the Department of Commerce to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation tonight to speed up the sale of surplus property. The change, made through an Executive Order, becomes effective on Nov. 5.

PARIS, Oct. 19--Maurice Thorez and Leon Blum, respective leaders of the Communist and Socialist parties, the outstanding protagonists in Sunday's general elections, crossed swords over France's foreign policy, the most heated issue of the campaign, in speeches over the French broadcasting system tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--Creation of a single national defense organization, in which the air arm will have coequal strength and influence with the Army and Navy, is essential if this country is to be prepared against future aggression, Gen. Henry H. Arnold, commander of the Army Air Forces, told the Senate Military Affairs Committee today.

THE HAGUE, Oct. 19--The Netherlands is painstakingly scraping together the semblance of an army for the task of subduing the unruly Nationalist elements in the East Indies. The opposition is not expected to be lion-hearted, so the force being despatched from here is considered powerful enough to fulfill this important mission.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--The personal automobiles of Adolf Hitler and of Hermann Goering rolled through this city today in a freight car.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., Oct. 19(AP) --Fourteen horses passed the entry box today as the skies cleared for the sixth, running of the $75,000 added Hollywood Gold Cup race at Hollywood Park tomorrow.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 19--The general strike ended at midnight and Argentina, after a week of turmoil, chaos and unexpected events, was rapidly returning today to what for many months past it had been obliged to regard as a normal condition.

KINGS LYNN, England, Oct. 19--A butter boat from Denmark and a cargo of bulbs from the Netherlands, the first since the war, were unloaded this week at this 1,000-year-old port, situated on the Great Ouse River, where it flows into The Wash.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 19--A mechanism for determining blood volume, a newly developed process for the production of riboflavin, and more improvements in synthetic rubber are among the 478 inventions listed as patented in the current issue of The Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.
MOSCOW, Oct. 19--The Red Army, not the atomic bomb, struck, the decisive blow at Japan, according to Nikolai Bogdano, writing in the Red Star today.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 19-- More than fifty persons were reported killed and 100 wounded today in a revolt by young army officers that unseated President Isaias Medina Angarita and apparently left the revolutionaries in control of Venezuela.

Sixth Avenue, which recently became the Avenue of the Americas by a stroke of Mayor La Guardia's pen, will have its official christening today at 12:30 P.M., when Juan Antonio Rios, President of Chile, places a new street sign in a bracket on a lamp post attached to a reviewing stand at Forty-first Street and Bryant Park.

Hatcher Hughes, playwright and Columbia University professor, who won a Pulitzer Prize for 1924 with his play "Hell-Bent for Heaven," died early yesterday of coronary thrombosis in his home at 39 Claremont Avenue. His age was 64.

VIENNA, Oct. 19--An appeal to Americans to understand and support Austria's claim to the return of South Tyrol by Italy was made in an interview today by Dr. Karl Gruber, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs in the Austrian Provisional Government.
Cotton futures were moderately active Friday and closed steady 1 to 9 points higher, with near-by position strongest.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--The House passed by acclamation tonight a bill rescinding authorizations for Federal expenditures aggregating $52,000,000,000. Lieut. Comdr. Lawrence French, of the Battleship New York, which is here to join in the Navy Day celebration, expects to be plain Southpaw Larry French in plenty of time to join the Brooklyn Dodgers for 1946 spring training at Daytona Beach.

The Meurice, thirteen-story residential hotel at 145 West Fiftyeighth Street, has been sold, according to reports in realty circles yesterday.

Tony Janiro, Youngstown (Ohio) welterweight, defeated Al Guido of Harlem in the feature bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. A crowd of 4,283 fans saw the contest, which was pathetically one-sided. All three officials, the referee and judges, awarded every round to Janiro.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 19--David Dubinsky of New York, president of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, was elected today to the executive council of the American Federation of Labor. Georges Bidault, Foreign Minister of France, declared last night, in a message to The New York Herald Tribune's 1945 Forum on Current Problems, held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, that "President Truman's lofty Navy Day speech struck a deeply responsive chord in us."
The Stage Door Canteen served as a lively and democratic host to more than three million servicemen in New York since opening the doors for its first show on March 2, 1942.

WIESBADEN, Oct. 30--The late October days on the Main and the Neckar are as mild and golden as Indian summer on the upper reaches of the Hudson.

Swift Co. boasts the largest commercial test kitchen in the world, and this fall its experts have been working out new recipes for a food that is particularly appetizing at this time of year-- sausage.
Joe Dickerson, 25-year-old guard for the University of Pennsylvania, won this week's Associated Press poll as the "lineman of the week" for his outstanding play against Navy last Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30--A civilian committee, after an exhaustive survey of the air war in, Europe, declared today that, while Allied air power was "decisive" in forcing Germany's defeat, a number of phases of the strategic bombing campaign were ineffective in their long-range results.

ATLANTA, Oct. 31 (U.P)--Robert Elliott Burns, fugitive from a Georgia chain gang, was reported on his way to Atlanta tonight to surrender and to ask for a pardon.

Any hopes that supporters of Columbia's unbeaten and untied football machine had entertained of the Lions playing in the Rose Bowl or any other post-season game were dispelled yesterday when Ralph Furey, Director of Athletics, recalled the university's position on bowl games. "Our season will end with the Dartmouth contest on Nov. 24," he declared.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP)--Baseball will find pickings unusually slim in the annual player draft tomorrow as representatives of the major league clubs meet to comb the minor leagues for fresh talent for the 1946 season.

ALBANY, Oct. 31 (AP)--Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein said today that a 10 per cent increase in interstate freight rates effective throughout the Northeast on Jan. 1 was based on an "erroneous conception" of bringing about freight rate uniformity. The increase, ordered by the Interstate Commerce Commission, would affect manufactured goods.

Blue Cross medical plans have doubled in number and enrollment during the last year, it was reported yesterday at the Blue Cross Plan conference of the American Hospital Association at the Hotel Commodore.

A net increase last week of 3,150,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Civilian grade gasoline supplies were up 2,638,000 barrels to 47,602,000, compared with 39,757,000 a year ago, and military grade increased 512,000 to 26,733,000, against 38,825,000 a year earlier.

Three of the great peacetime military problems that must be settled within the next few months have now been presented to Congress. One is the size of the Navy that will be needed. Another is the question of universal military training, which bears directly on the size of the post-war Army.

Completing one of the busiest four-month periods in the history of new financing, investment bankers in October offered to the public $855,423,000 in thirty-nine new issues of bonds and $150,591,000 in thirty-five new issues of stock.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, expressed the belief here yesterday that public expectations over the possible achievements of the labormanagement conference opening Monday in Washington were much too naive, and declared the most ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--President Truman said today that the entire field of atomic energy and no other subject was on the agenda of his forthcoming discussions with Prime Ministers Attlee and Mackenzie King, although he welcomed a discussion of any other matters they cared to bring into the conference.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 31-- The police of Montclair reported proudly today that they had solved a case of attempted extortion that has been on the books of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for more than seven years.

Bill Irons, whose play at center since he was released from the Army has plugged a gaping hole in the New York University line, will not be at his customary position when the Violets play Rochester Saturday on Ohia Field.

THE Athletic Institute has as its principal objective the spreading of the gospel of physical fitness through competitive ath letics. Everyone knows what a shock it was to discover through Selective Service that one-third of those drafted were rejected as unfit and therefore the organization is boosting sports "for a stronger and healthier America."

The earnings of the racing stable that Mrs. Elizabeth N. Graham has built up through the assistance of her chief adviser, Leslie Combs 2d, and her sagacious trainer, Silent Tom Smith, soared over the halfmillion mark yesterday when ...

MOSCOW, Oct. 31--In the first comment on President Truman's Navy Day speech to appear in Moscow newspapers, K. Gofman, the able columnist of the Red Star, said today that the speech was a timely reminder for those who inclined to forget that "the roots of fascism and militarism have not yet been destroyed."

LONDON, Oct. 31--The decision of the New Zealand Government to repay more than 23,000,000 of stocks gave the gilt-edge market a fillip today, old Consols rising to a new high mark with a gain of five-eights point. Local loans were also better.

What makes an ideal football player? The question was put directly to Lou Little, head man at Columbia. Now, Lou is knee-deep in trouble, fretting about the types of offense and defense his young charges will employ against Cornell at Baker Field on Saturday, but the veteran mentor, nevertheless, took time out and tackled the problem.

LONDON, Oct. 31 (AP)--Wincenty Witos, vice president of the Polish National Council and a figure in Polish politics for half a century, died today in Cracow, the British Broadcasting Corporation said tonight. His age was 71.

While audience measurement of all advertising is subject to mistakes, the margin for error in the case of newspapers and magazines is narrowed because of Audit Bureau of Circulation figures, Alfred Politz, research expert, declared yesterday.
BERLIN, Oct. 31--A high British officer today predicted severe suffering for the German people during the coming winter, but he said that this would be largely their own fault.

American Art Week, which begins today, is being observed this year with several exhibitions. One, of work by members of the American Artists Professional League, New York Chapter, may be seen at the National Arts Club.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Oct. 31--Leaders of German public opinion in the United States zone of occupation are strongly opposed to United States Supreme Court Justice Robert H. Jackson's proposal to try to punish German ...

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 31-- Irene Dunne is about to be signed by Twentieth Century-Fox to portray Anna, the English tutor, in the forthcoming "Anna and the King of Siam." Miss Dunne previously had declined the role due to the illness of her husband. Now that he is recovering and in view of the belated start of production, the actress has reconsidered.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 31--Still sore in body from the battering it took on Franklin Field, but high in spirit and brimful of confidence, Navy will up anchor tomorrow night and steam for Cleveland, seeking its first victory there over Notre Dame since 1934 as a parting gift for its coach.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated yesterday over a fairly wide range and closed 6 points lower to 2 points higher than on Tuesday.

It will be all right for lawyers, returning to civilian practice after service in the armed forces, to advertise any specialized wartime legal duties they performed for Government bureaus, according to an opinion made public yesterday by the New York Bar Association's committee on professional ethics.

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, said yesterday that if "proper guarantees" that high-point troops would be homeward bound by Christmas were lacking, he would recommend that the NMU's ...

Indications are that the holiday season this year will be a good bit less restrained so far as entertaining is concerned, and for obvious reasons. Aside from homecomings and reunions that call for celebration, the fact that many foods are easier to come by than formerly gives impetus to the party mood.

A couple of accounts of successful moose-hunting expeditions in Canada arrived at this desk yesterday. One was from Jule Marshall of Larchmont, who reported that his friend Fred Bear was back in Detroit after a real feat--taking a 1,500-pound moose with bow and arrow.

Reflecting recent large-scale refinancing, bonds called before maturity for payment in October amounted to $677,546,000, the largest sum for a month in more than nineteen years. The total compared with $223,682,000 in the preceding month and with $160,486,000 in October, 1944.

DETROIT, Oct. 31--Moving to capitalize upon the recommendations of President Truman that wages be lifted, the United Automobile Workers, CIO, demanded today that the General Motors Corporation reconsider its rejection of the union demand for a blanket payroll increase of 30 per cent and...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--The House debated the additional $550,000,000 appropriation for the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration today in an atmosphere indicating certain approval of the fund required to complete this country's $1,350,000,000 commitment, but with distince reservations as to its use and management.

LONDON, Oct. 31--Prime Minister Attlee will propose on behalf of Britain that the secret of the atomic bomb be turned over to the Security Council of the United Nations Organization, it was reliably reported today.

LONDON, Oct. 31--Gordon Richards, England's champion jockey, raised his winning rides up to 3,000 today when he piloted Exotic first past the finish line in the Icklingham Stakes at Newmarket today. He became the first jockey to accomplish this feat on the British turf.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--President Truman declared unequivocally today that he expected the Soviet Union to join the Far Eastern Advisory Commission, which has delayed its organization here because of the absence of the Russians.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--The Federal Government's first inspection of income and asset data on tax-exempt organizations, such as labor unions, is expected to show annual untaxed income of around $3,000,000,000, and untaxed assets possibly exceeding $15,000,000,000 ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--The National Coordinating Board, representing American Federation of Labor members employed by the Western Union Telegraph Company and some unaffiliated employes petitioned the National Labor Relations Board today for a strike vote in the dispute involving wage demands.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 31 (U.P.) --The Brazilian armed forces are united in their determination to eradicate the last vestiges of the "dictatorship" that they overthrew two days ago, it was officially announced tonight after the first meeting of provisional President Josh Linhares' Cabinet.

TOKYO, Oct. 31--Allied headquarters tonight issued its second important order on the re-education of the Japanese, directing the Imperial Ministry of Education itself to find a means of screening teachers and seeing that militarists and ultranationists do not remain in the Japanese school system.

Men's hat volume in retail stores unexpectedly made gains far above the most optimistic industry estimates during October, it was learned yesterday. Dollar sales reached an all-time high figure. Inventories are depleted to an extent ...
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Oct. 31--The Cleveland Rams, who are working out here this week, promise to put on quite a football show against the Giants at the Polo Grounds Sunday.
Dividend payments on the 877 common stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange increased 4.2 per cent in the first nine months of this year over the like period of 1944 with a total of payments ...

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP)--League statistics show that the surprisefilled race has failed to produce a single touchdown by a punt or kick-off return in 307 chances, while Green Bay has fumbled eleven times in five games, equalling its season total last year when the Packers established a new ballhandling record.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 31--Spence Wildey, art editor of The Woman's Home Companion since 1943 and a well-known designer, died today in New Rochelle Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 39. His office was at 250 Park Avenue, New York, and his home at 195 Griffin Avenue, Scarsdale, N.Y.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 31--Frank M. Folsom, executive vice president in charge of the RCA-Victor division of the Radio Corporation of America, criticized President Truman's new wage-price policy today on the ground that it meant a six months' gamble with stockholders' money while waiting for ...

The new report of General Eisenhower on Allied rule in Germany paints a frankly unsatisfactory and in part disturbing picture of the situation. Having abolished the German Government, the Allies set up under the Yalta and Potsdam agreements a Central...

Harvard University Press has listed the first two of four volumes of "The Letters and Private Papers of William Makepeace Thackeray" for publication Nov. 15. The material was collected and edited by Gordon N. Ray, a graduate of the University of Indiana, who ...

LONDON, Oct. 31--A demand that Italy be required to pay a total reparations bill of $300,000,000, of which one-third would be given to the Soviet Union and the rest would go to Yugoslavia, Greece and Albania, while Britain and the United States should waive any share, has now been put forth by Russia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--A 30 per cent annual increase in civil aircraft will result in 1955 in an aviation industry which will use 400,000 airplanes, carry 20,000,000 passengers and directly and indirectly provide jobs for 901,300 persons, according to a forecast made today by the Civil Aeronautics Administration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--Edwin W. Pauley, head of the American Reparations Commission, announced today that part of Emperor Hirohito's personal fortune, estimated at more than $100,000,000, would be claimed to pay war reparations to the Allies.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 31 (AP)--Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark's Boojum II and W.H. Lipscomb's Mercator won the two divisions of the two-mile Jervis Spencer Steeplechase Handicap at Pimlico today. It was believed to be the first time in American racing history that a major jumping event was split.

MOSCOW, Oct. 31 (AP)--The first indication that Russia might participate in the 1948 Olympics was seen in an announcement today that Soviet soccer football teams were being sent to Great Britain, Rumania, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia for a series of international matches.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31--Grain markets were strong in the early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade with December and May rye selling at new seasonal peaks, but irregularity developed and the ...

BISBEE, Ariz., Oct. 31--With his faithful dog standing guard beside him, Michael McDonald, 2 year-old son of a cowboy, was found unharmed today by members of a posse of more than 200 persons rallied by radio to hunt for him after he became lost yesterday in the wild countryside.

Persons who love antiques for their own sake rather than as trappings for a pageant of the past have come more and more to appreciate the way a subdued modern background enhances the delicate lines and glowing woods of old cabinetwork.

LONDON, Oct. 31--A joint commission to be established under an Anglo-American agreement on Palestine will investigate the position of Jews in Europe as well as the situation in Palestine itself, it was reported authoritatively tonight as Dr. Chaim Weizmann ...

With extension until March 1 of Federal assistance to child care centers, originally set to end today, twenty-eight such centers in this State have four months more to work out new arrangements for financing.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP)--The Black Hawks served notice tonight they may be a definite threat in the National Hockey League race this season as they concentrated their power in the first and third periods to defeat the Rangers, 5--1, before a crowd of 18,877, largest opening-game crowd in the history of hockey in this city.
Not in years in this city has a singer received such a welcome as was extended Maggie Teyte when, after an interval of many seasons, she returned to New York for a recital last night in Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--President Truman refused today to set a maximum percentage for wage increases as Congress split, mostly along party lines, on his speech last night, in which he called for reasonable pay rises without major increases in prices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--James F. Byrnes, Secretary of State, absolved Cordell Hull, former Secretary of State, today of the charges that his note of Nov. 26, 1941, to Japan touched off the attack on Pearl Harbor.

Continued absorption of discharged members of the armed forces by brokerage houses and investment banking firms was revealed yesterday in reports of changes in firm personnel and the creation of new firms.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month, despite the various holidays, expanded to the largest total since June and for a corresponding month since 1938. Sales exceeded the million-share mark in every full day's session, ...

Seven warships left New York Harbor yesterday. All that remained of the fifty-one ships reviewed by President Truman last Saturday--Navy Day--were a few destroyers, submarines and the battleships Missouri and New York.

Three detectives of the West Fifth-fouth Street station captured yesterday afternoon a six-man team believed by the police to be responsible for a wave of robberies and muggings of service men in the midtown area in recent weeks. In addition they seized a cache of stolen items valued roughly at several thousand dollars.
KALGAN, Inner Mongolia, Oct. 11 (Delayed)--Communism in China today is essentially an application of the age-old doctrine that the end justifies the means.

Gifts of money ranging from $1 to $50,000 and the special gift of a 109-carat diamond were announced yesterday at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel opening the New York campaign for funds to construct a ...

Mayor La Guardia charged yesterday that the election of William O'Dwyer, Democratic and American Labor party candidate for Mayor, would mean a return to the city of "the old saloon with all its old subsidiaries, sales to minors, after-hours operation and vice of all kinds."

Acton Griscom, banker, and John Griffin, butler, got together in a Yorkville Court antechamber yesterday and amicably settled a misunderstanding they had the night of Oct. 24 at a cocktail party in the Countess de Beaumont's fifteenthfloor apartment at 510 Park Avenue.
James F. Byrnes, Secretary of State, said last night that the United States recognized the special security interests of the Soviet Union in her Central and Eastern European neighbors.

PARIS, Oct. 31--The Argentine workers' delegate and his adviser were excluded from the International Labor Office's conference today with resounding applause by a unanimous vote of 119 voices approving the credentials committee's recommendation.

In a cash deal, the five-story dwelling at 158 East Seventieth Street was sold by Mrs. Woodward Babcock to a New York buyer for occupancy. It is 19.7 by 100.5 feet and was sold through Douglas L. Elliman Co., the seller being represented by Pease Elliman.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)-- Josephus Daniels told a Senate committee today that the time had come to modernize national defense by combining air, land and sea power under a single Cabinet department.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (U.P.)-- Four members of the House Military Affairs Committee joined labor leaders today in charging that proposed legislation imposing new curbs on labor unions discriminated against labor by not providing penalties against employers.

QUEBEC, Oct. 31--A spokesman for the Canadian delegation to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization today called for the elimination of tariff barriers on the ground that they represent one of the chief obstacles to the FAO's program for ending worldwide hunger.

Election of Judge Jonah J. Goldstein, Republican--Liberal--Fusion candidate for Mayor, "by a close but comfortable margin" was predicted last night by the Independent Citizens Committee for Goldstein-McGoldrick-Pette on the basis of a poll it made covering onethird of the sixty-seven Assembly districts in the city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)-- Revision of the GI Bill of Rights to make it easier for veterans to go to school at Government expense or get loans in buying homes, farms or businesses was recommended today by a Senate committee.

James R. Murphy, real estate auctioneer and broker, long one of the leaders in his field in the city, died yesterday of a heart attack in his room at the New York Athletic Club, where he had been living temporarily since the sale in ...

Mayor La Guardia initiated a series of conferences yesterday with representatives of the milk industry and the teamsters' union in an effort to prevent a tie-up of milk distribution threatened by the dispute over the continuation of skip-a-day milk deliveries.

At the earliest annual preliminary budget hearing ever held, the Committee on Finance and Budget of the Board of Education heard outlined yesterday a program for the establishment of five to seven adult centers in this city for "the promotion of intercultural relations and citizenship education."

George J. Beldock, Kings County District Attorney, charged last night that William O'Dwyer in his broadcast of the previous evening had sustained the charges of laxity, inefficiency and maladministraiton leveled at the Democratic--American Labor candidate for Mayor by the special Kings County Grand Jury.
Governors of the New York Curb Exchange approved yesterday the first payment of incentive bonuses to employes under a plan retroactive to Jan. 1.

Four of five Borough Presidents are candidates for re-election. One of these four--Edgar J. Nathan Jr. of Manhattan--has given his borough a notably efficient and progressive administration, and this newspaper has already urged his re-election.

The report of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company issued yesterday by William F. Humphrey, president, shows for the nine months ended with September a consolidated net income of $13,583,969, compared with $12,485,953 earned in the first nine months of 1944.

TOKYO, Oct. 31--A gaudy imitation of "big-time" racketeering operations--replete with women, liquor and the smuggling of precious stones--was uncovered simultaneously last night with the smashing of the tremendous black market ring.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31--For the first time since 12,000 San Francisco Bay area machinists went on strike Monday, throwing some 35,000 union workers into idleness, the Federal Conciliation Service got management and union leaders together today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--The first of January was set today by Robert H. Hinckley, director of Contract Settlement, as the calendar target for completing the task of contract settlement.

The War Advertising Council today becomes the Advertising Council. The war group, representing all branches of advertising activity, which for three years and ten months contributed its services exclusively to government agencies, under its new name will inaugurate a peacetime program of public service, James W. Young, chairman, announced yesterday.

The City Planning Commission submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday a capital budget of $295,252,131 for 1946, a reduction of $7,799,680 from the proposed $303,051,811 budget on which it held a public hearing on Oct. 17.
MADRID, Oct. 31--Ignazio Zuloaga, internationally famous Spanish painter, died in his studio home here this morning. His age was 75. He had been in poor health for some time.

Reporting on operations of the General Foods Corporation for the first nine months of this year, Clarence Francis, chairman of the board, announced yesterday a net profit of $11,261,990 after all charges, equal to $2.02 a share on 5,575,463 common shares.

After a year of preparation and testing, the work of a group of psychologists and educators who applied scientific research methods to uncovering the causes of trouble in communities tense with racial difficulties and then set about making the residents cure their own problems, was made public here yesterday.

Capital stock increases were approved yesterday by stockholders of three banks--the Merchants Bank, the Chemical Bank and Trust Company and the Federation Bank and Trust Company. Increase in the capital of the Garden City Bank and Trust Company was recommended, too, by that bank's directors.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 31 (U.P)--Provisional President Romulo Betancourt said today that a National Assembly would be chosen soon to rewrite the Constitution, and that a President would be elected by free balloting within six months.

Sales of Victory Bonds to individuals throughout the nation in the first two days of the eighth loan drive have exceeded expectations, it was announced yesterday in Washington as Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, issued an appeal there for support of the campaign.

The steel industry began the paring away of old and inefficient facilities in 1944, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute's statistical report for the year, issued yesterday. Included among abandoned and dismantled facilities were certain plants too old for use in meeting emergency wartime demands.

The National War Fund campaign to raise $115,000,000 throughout the nation probably will last several weeks longer than planned in most communities owing to "slower collections because of the industrial reconversion," it was reported yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 31--A suggestion that Britain have a post-war period of four to five years in which to adjust her trade balance before joining a world movement for the reduction of trade barriers was advanced today by Donald L. Gill, executive secretary of the American Chamber of Commerce of London.
LONDON, Oct. 31--Henry Ainley, the Shakespearean actor, died today in his London home after a long illness. He was 66 years old.

To avoid placing retailers in an unfair position, ceiling-price increases of 5 to 6 cents a pound on all grades of sweet and salted butter will go into effect today instead of next Thursday as had previously been announced, Leo F. Gentner, acting regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, said yesterday.

First commercial use of aluminum alloy for piano plates, permitting the production of pianos light enough to be moved with a minimum effort was demonstrated at a preview held yesterday afternoon by Winter Co., one of the largest piano manufacturers, at the Sherry Netherland Hotel.

Still undefeated in the finals for the United States Chess Federation amateur title, Marcy Hanft of Brooklyn took undisputed possession of the lead last night at the Marshall Chess Club when he defeated C.F. Tears Jr. in the eighth round.
The fourteen-story office building at 138-42 Nassau Street, northeast corner of Beekman Street, has been purchased by an investor from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.
Col. and Mrs. J. Murray Mitchell of Tuxedo Park have come to Mayfair House.

The coming struggle between the railroads and the airlines for the coach passenger business was outlined before the Kiwanis Club of New York at its luncheon meeting in the Hotel McAlpin yesterday by William Littledale, vice ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--The United States, Great Britain, the Soviet Union and China have agreed to destroy the major remnants of the Japanese Fleet--one battleship, four aircraft carriers, four cruisers and fifty-one submarines--and to divide equally the ...
Twenty-six realty and trade associations have joined in approval of a resolution petitioning Congress and the Office of Price Administration to remove rent ceilings from new construction as ...
The hobgoblins and witches of Halloween came early and stayed late yesterday afternoon at the thirty-fourth annual party of the Madison Square Boys Club, 301 East Twenty-ninth Street.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP)--Laurence F. Lee, president of the American Life Convention, said today that life insurance companies have "carefully refrained from any activity that might be considered political," but they now "must take a definite position in certain cases although they may take on political aspects."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--Publishers were warned today by the War Production Board to expect a reduction of 15 per cent in newsprint orders for deliveries in December as a result of accumulated over-orders for the fourth quarter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (U.P.)-- Leaders of big AFL and CIO unions announced tonight that they would attempt to use President Truman's wage-price policy statement as a lever to break the log-jam of wage disputes.

LONDON, Oct. 31--Announcing that he had just received the Soviet reply to British protests against the Russo-Hungarian and RussoRumanian trade agreements, Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin, administered a pointed rebuke to Moscow today for its "bilateral procedure" in these cases.

PONTIAC, Mich., Oct. 31--The body of a young woman who had been shot through the temple was recovered today from the Clinton River, eighteen miles from the scene of the unsolved murder of Mrs. Lydia Thompson, Russianborn wife of a Highland Park automobile dealer.

Improved earnings for the nine months period this year were reported by the Union Oil Company of California whose statement yesterday disclosed a net profit of $7,323,796 or $1.52 a share of common stock.
The country's industrial leaders generally withheld comment yesterday on President Truman's speech outlining his wage-price policy for reconversion.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--The Office of Price Administration announced today manufacturers' ceiling prices for work clothes made of seven types of cotton textile materials will be increased on Nov. 5 by the exact dollar-and-cents amounts of price rises granted recently to mills producing the fabrics.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 31 (AP)-- Final approval by the State Racing Commission of plans for a horseracing track at Oceanport, Monmouth County, were deferred today pending Compliance by the Monmouth Park Jockey Club, owner of the proposed oval, with a commission request that Lou Smith of Long Branch withdraw as a stockholder in the club.

LONDON, Oct. 31--Winston Churchill became a world figure because he failed in his boyhood ambition to become a kettledrum player, he confessed tonight at the annual reunion of his old school at Harrow.

The Board of Estimate cleared the way yesterday for the beginning of work on the new civic center in downtown Brooklyn by voting unanimously to acquire all privately owned land and buildings in the region bounded by Fulton, Sands, Washington and Jay Streets.
After two weeks of consultation with traffic specialists, Borough President Edgar J. Nathan Jr. made public yesterday a "plan to alleviate traffic congestion in midtown Manhattan."

CHICAGO, Oct. 31--Political strikes, intended not to redress economic grievances but to force the Government to take action desired by a labor group, are beginning to harass the United States and should be quickly forbidden by law, Donald R. Richberg declared in an address here today.

LONDON, Oct. 31--Soviet Union support for the establishment of a world youth federation was announced today by Nicola A. Mikhailoff, 38-year-old secretary of the Russian Young Communist League and leader of the Soviet delegation to the World Youth Conference.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--President Truman, through a letter from Gen Dwight D. Eisenhower, outlined today plans for turning over the Government of Germany to the Allies civil authorities in concert with the other occupying powers not latter than June 1.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 8 (AP) --An amateur won the North and South open golf tournament today for the first time in the 44-year history of this fixture, when Lieut. Cary Middlecoff of Memphis, with a 72-hole total of 280, beat Denny Shute of Akron, Ohio, by five strokes.

ATHENS, Greece, Nov. 8--Continued acts of violence against Greek communities in southern Albania, including murder, abduction, arbitrary imprisonment, mass deportation and house burning, are reported in an official study by the Greek Government, supported by a mass of purported detail.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 8 --Nationalist armies deployed along the Great Wall of China have opened an offensive to break through the Shanhaikwan Pass into southern Manchuria and fierce fighting is raging, Communist sources said today.

Supplies in the city's food markets have remained fairly static during the week; in fact, about the only changes have been in stocks of salt-water fish and veal, which are much larger than last Friday.

After seven weeks of testimony the House Expenditures Committee has closed its hearings on "full employment" legislation by appointing a subcommittee of five which the chairman "hopes" will draft some sort of courpromise measure.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 8 (AP) --For the first time since Pearl Harbor the inmates of this austere stone fortress were permitted tonight to unbend and generally raise the roof in the time-honored prelude to the Notre Dame game.
The thirty-eighth annual autumn exhibition of the Horticultural So ciety of New York opened yester day in the Penn Top of the Hotel Pennsylvania.

TOKYO, Nov. 8 (U.P.)--Japanese Home Minister Zenjiro Horikiri, in charge of Japanese police forces, escaped unhurt last night when a demobilized Kamikaze suicide flier tried to assassinate him with a pocket knife, it was disclosed today. The attacker and an accomplice were arrested.

Two more victims of early-hour mugging attacks have died in Brooklyn hospitals, bringing the total number of deaths from beatings and robberies in the borough to five in the last month, it became known yesterday. Both were men. The three previous victims were women.

The earning assets position of the reporting member banks in New York City of the Federal Reserve System for the week ended on Wednesday showed a decrease of $58,000,000, of which loans showed the greatest decline.

A bank for national recovery has been established by the Ministry of Finance of the Netherlands with a capital of 300,000,000 guilder, or about $114,000,000, it was announced here yesterday by the Netherlands Government information bureau.

Plumbers employed by Bronx and Manhattan contractors who have not agreed to a restoration of a pre-war six-hour day will be called out on strike this morning William T. Dodd, president of Local 2, United Association of Plumbers, American Federation of Labor, announced yesterday.

Negotiations are in progress for the acquisition of the Tubize Rayon Corporation by the Celanese Corporation of America, it was learned yesterday in well-informed Wall Street circles. Advent sermons will be preached at many churches tomorrow in preparation for the coming observance of Christmas.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30--Old-crop deliveries of rye broke 2 5/8 to 2 cents a bushel early today on the Board of Trade, as the result of confusion arising from announcement by the Office of Price Administration late yesterday of a ceiling price of $1.42 on No. 2 rye on the 1946 crop.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 30 (AP)-- Twice blacked out by the war, Florida's 120-day winter racing season will get under way at 1:15 P. M. tomorrow with some of the nation's top thoroughbreds featuring a nine-race program at picturesque Gulfstream Park, fourteen miles north of this city.

Christmas demand for consumer merchandise will exceed all previous records, yet a break-down of department-store inventories, despite the fact that they are at fairly high levels, promises acute holiday shortages in many lines, the Monthly Review of Credit and Business Conditions of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--Naval aviation, vital for amphibious operations, fleet reconnaissance and anti-submarine warfare, must remain a separate entity as part of a national strategy to maintain air pre-eminence through landbased and sea-borne air forces, Rear Admiral Forrest P. Sherman told the Senate Military Affairs Committee today.
The Equitable Securities Corporation and associates yesterday bought an issue of 2 per cent Lake Worth, Fla., water and electric revenue certificates totaling $850,000. The successful bid was 97.203.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 30-- One of football's oldest rivalries will be resumed tomorrow when Harvard and Yale meet in the Bowl.

Employes of the Western Union Telegraph Company voted 5,277 to 478 in favor of a strike, according to results announced yesterday by Mrs. Marjorie Himes, examiner of the National Labor Relations Board.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 30--More than 2,000 Polish Jews, most of whom have been supported in Palestine since 1941 by the British Government to the extent of more than $3,000,000, will have to look elsewhere for support after Jan. 1, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--Herbert H. Lehman, Director General of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, exclaiming that it was "unfortunate indeed that UNRRA at this critical time should have to defend itself against erroneous press reports," ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--The text of the program for minimizing industrial disputes, which the management delegates made public at the closing session of the Labor-Management Conference, is as follows (it is not an official conference document):

Expenditure of several millions of dollars for new equipment in the post-war period is planned by numerous breweries, members of the New York State Brewers' Association, spokesmen for the organization announced yesterday at the annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria.

David W. Frankel has purchased the five-story forty-three-family apartment house at 2807 Claflin Avenue, southwest corner of 197th Street, the Bronx, from Jesse Albert Back, who acquired the property nineteen years ago.

The type of international teamwork that went into the development of the atomic bomb could be applied, with profitable results both for the world and science, to other scientific problems in many fields, it was declared here yesterday by the British biologist Dr. Julian Huxley.

LONDON, Nov. 30--Scientists must become part of a world society that banishes war if they want to preserve their particular freedoms, Prime Minister Attlee said tonight at a dinner following the Royal Society's 283d anniversary meeting.
WASHINGTON, Nov.30--About $4,000,000 has been recovered from about 450 railroads as a result of readjustment of freight rates for armor plate, the Department of Justice announced today.
The snow that arrived in the State for the last day of the deer season, far from enhancing the hunters' chances for a record kill, very likely brought about a reduced take.

The miraculous rescue of a young sailor who was washed overboard from the big battleship Washington in mid-Atlantic was related when the warship arrived here early yesterday with her first contingent of redeployed GI's from Europe.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 30 (AP)--A new enemy of four types of anemia has been discovered, researchers at the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--The House passed and sent to the Senate today a deficiency appropriation bill carrying $1,435,267,312 to meet supplemental needs of a large number of Federal agencies between now and next June 30. The net increase over committee recommendations was $303,815,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)--A group of House Republicans, young in Congress, gave notice today they intend to express their own views on major matters and not allow party leaders to speak for them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--An additional 15,000 physicians and 5,000 dentists were made eligible for discharge from the Army under a plan announced late today by Secretary Robert P. Patterson. Point requirements are to be reduced from 80 to 70.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (U.P.)-- Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson called tonight on the nation's farmers to exceed slightly last year's crop acreage by planting 356,244,000 acres in 1946 to fulfill the still "almost unlimited need for food."

A full appreciation by management of the cumulative effect of its day-to-day decisions on the national economy was urged by President Truman in a letter to the Society for the Advancement of Management read last night at its annual dinner meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--Linking the recent concentration of British troops in Palestine with British "concern" about establishing a military base in the Middle East, Senator Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine told the Senate today that "it is understood" there ...
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--The Anglo-American loan negotiators were reported in tentative agreement tonight on nearly all major aspects of a financial and commercial agreement.

With a three-inch white blanket on the big tarpaulin that covers the playing field at the Polo Grounds, the football Giants, previously hampered by rain, yesterday found themselves snowbound when they gathered for another workout in preparation for tomorrow's clash with the Philadelphia Eagles.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 30-- The elementary business of keeping alive and keeping healthy while you're at it occupied primary attention among inventors who received the 456 patents listed in this week's Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

Net profit of American Airlines, Inc., for the first nine months of this year increased to $4,059,843 from $3,991,688 for the corresponding period of 1944, despite increased operating costs and taxes, the report of C. R. Smith, chairman of the board, disclosed yesterday.

VIENNA, Nov. 30--Reduction to the size of the occupation armies, abolition of zonal demarcation and enlargement of the powers of the new Austrian Government are being considered by the Allied Council fgor Austria.

BOSTON, Nov. 30--Massachusetts manufacturers generally agree that the buying public must share a major portion of wage increases in the form of higher prices to enable industry to reach fullscale production in the post-war period.

PARIS, Nov. 30--The International Women's Congress, at its concluding session today, adopted a resolution demanding that the atomic bomb be submitted to the control of the United Nations after hearing Mrs. Gifford Pinchot of the United States and Mrs. Pat Clarke of Britain declare that the United States and Britain were not justified in keeping the secret to themselves.
Wage payments have a twofold impact: they affect costs of production and they contribute to the worker's purchasing power.

In calling attention to the sharp increase of youthful offender cases in Brooklyn, District Attorney George J. Beldock announced yesterday that a Youth Council Bureau would be established in that borough to specialize in the handling of juvenile delinquents, "particularly to supplement the work now being performed by the probation departments and other agencies."
Holding within a 10-point range, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady yesterday and closed 4 to 9 points net higher.
LONDON, Nov. 30--The stock markets here were depressed generally today by political and labor uncertainties.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--Maj. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley refused today to testify before a closed session of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Wednesday in an inquiry into the background of his dramatic resignation as Ambassador to Chungking.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 30--Millions of dollars in Japanese assets here have "vanished" along with German holdings through the conversion of enemy wealth into gold bars, real estate and neutral foreign exchange under assumed names and the camouflaging of property ownership by Chinese, White Russian and Portuguese dummies.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 30 (AP)--The Maine Chance Farm pulled another ace out of the deck today as Colony Boy splashed to victory in the fortieth Walden Stakes, while Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' Stymie romped away with the grueling two-and-ahalf-mile Pimlico Cup, co-feature on Pimlico's getaway program.

Lester B. Granger, executive secretary of the National Urban League, appealed yesterday to the National Bar Association to "join forces in a national project to make it impossible for public funds to be spent in what amounts to a practical subsidy of racial ghetto buildings in American cities."

NUREMBERG, Germany, Nov. 30--In a complete reversal of his role so far, Rudolf Hess dramatically joined the argument as to his ability to stand trial as a war criminal today by rising in court and announcing that he was sane, that he had been shamming his amnesia, and that he accepted full responsibility for all that he had done.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--The Office of Price Administration gave authority today for increases of 5 to 65 cents a ton in the ceiling prices allowed to producers of anthracite coal.

LONDON, Nov. 30--Britain's export trade in the third quarter of this year fails to reflect any results of the world-wide trade expansion program upon which the nation has launched, according to figures made public today by the Board of Trade.
TOKYO, Nov. 30--Japan is forbidden to plan, design, print or issue new currency without the approval of Supreme Allied Headquarters, according to an order today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 30 (AP)--About 600 German military internees, including 100 who attempted suicide, were hospitalized tonight after a day of violence as the Swedish Government started extradition of 2,700 former Wehrmacht soldiers to Soviet territory.

November dollar volume in men's wear stores throughout the country, running far ahead of the like 1944 month and setting an alltime record, has placed retailers in the position of wondering, because of restricted shipments of fill-in lines for Christmas selling, what they are going to have to offer the public during the balance of the year.

James E. Markham, alien property custodian, yesterday held a meeting in his offices at 120 Broadway with seventy bankers, attorneys and engineers to give and receive views on the best methods of the disposal next year of controlling shares in American Potash and Chemical Corporation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 30-- The Hollywood Victory Committee, through which screen players have made 56,286 free patriotic wartime appearances, will wind up its operations on Dec. 31, according to an announcement by Kenneth Thom son, its chairman.
The city passed its quota yesterday in sales of Victory Loan bonds to individuals, with cumulative sales of $539,558,806, or 100.4 per cent of its goal.

Pre-season enthusiasm was running "ski-high" in the metropolitan area last night as heavy snows visited suburban areas and the north country, leaving in their wake a sufficient cover for unusually good skiing at this time of the season.
Now is the time of squaw winter and over the frost-browned hills the stars seem to hang low at night.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 (AP)-- The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today a request by a committee of holders of preferred stock of the Northern States Power Company (Delaware) for permission to inspect the company's list of stockholders and to receive a copy of the list upon payment of expenses involved.
December does not figure to be as active as November in matters theatrical, according to a survey made yesterday of producers' plans.
Small as Syria is, it has a great cuisine, if one is to judge by the meals served at the Mecca Restaurant, 6 East Thirtieth Street.
While General Yamashita, the conqueror of 1942, sat in a Manila courtroom this week President Osmena of the Philippine Commonwealth signed an order creating a national park on the Bataan Peninsula.

The New York Life Insurance Company sold the one-story building on a plot 32 by 141 feet at 29 Union Square West, southwest corner of Sixteenth Street, to an investing client of David Rapoport for a reported price of $120,000. Carstens Linnekin, brokers in the deal, said a resale to a restaurant chain was pending.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 30-- Venezuela's revolutionary junta has apparently smashed the only important political force still opposing it within the country as the result of yesterday's act in exiling former Presidents Eleazar Lopez ...

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in November expanded to the second largest total since the outbreak of war in September, 1939, and the turnover was the largest for a corresponding month since 1936.

Setting a goal of $2,000,000 for an advertising and promotional campaign, the National Cotton Council is engaged in setting up a nation-wide cotton promotion campaign, long projected but curtailed because of wartime shortages of cotton, it was disclosed here yesterday by Herbert Rogers, head of the Dallas, Tex., agency handling the account.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30-- First in peace as they were in war, Army and Navy bring back football's most glamorous spectacle to Philadelphia Municipal Stadium tomorrow for the first time since the week preceding the attack on Pearl Harbor.

A broad buying movement which encompassed every section of the stock market yesterday pushed prices to within a fractional range of their previous high marks, with rises of 1 to 2 points, while gains in some special situations ranged to 8 points.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 30 (AP)-- The late President Roosevelt's Scottie, Fala, although whipped in a tangle with Elliott Roosevelt's bull mastiff, Blaze, survives his rival at the family's Hyde Park estate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--A four-week labor-management conference failed to produce a shortcut formula for the prevention of strikes, but the delegates generally felt that the conference was not a failure.

Noting that drug-trade associations in some areas are endeavoring to get State governments to take over the governing of fair trade laws, Isaac W. Digges, general counsel for the American Fair Trade Council, warned yesterday that such a trend would lead to fixation of prices and dealers' discounts by States, taking the prerogative away from manufacturers.

A new program designed to provide veterans with free guidance in furnishing and decorating their homes was announced yesterday by Joseph Mullen, national president of the American Institute of Decorators.

LONDON, Nov. 30--Yugoslavia, formally proposing a suggestion made previously by the Soviet Union, asked at the United Nations Organization Preparatory Commission conference today that the League of Nations mandatory powers declare their intention to place their territories under UNO trusteeship.

Louis Phillips, 39-year-old discharged veteran and father of two children, rubbed his right shoulder, which had been injured by a V-2 bomb in England, and flexed his shrapnel-splintered fingers in his home at 1468 Seabury Place, the Bronx, yesterday as he discussed the problem of finding suitable employment.

One thing can safely be said about the Quonset Hut: it is better than a pup tent. Veterans home from the wars may have thought and hoped they had seen the last of Quonsets, but they were a little premature.
ROME, Saturday, Dec. 1--Alcide de Gasperi agreed shortly after midnight to undertake to form a new Government to serve Italy until a Constitutent Assembly has been elected in the spring.

The marriage of Miss Nancy Elizabeth Wadsworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eliot Wadsworth of Washington, formerly of Boston, to Pfc. Daniel Lewis Larson, AUS, son of Mrs. Charles Larson of Seattle and the late Mr. Larson, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30--When Army squared off against Penn here two weeks ago George Munger knew instinctively what would happen on the first two cadet running plays.

BATAVIA, Java, Nov. 30-- Indonesian gun positions that shelled camps around Ambarawa yesterday, killing former internees and former prisoners of war as well as British troops, were attacked in force today by Royal Air Force planes in the biggest air strike that has taken place so far on Java.

A capital outlay budget of $298,521,086 for 1946 was adopted yesterday by the Board of Estimate. It contemplates the expenditure of that sum in city funds, with the expectation that $217,228,906 of Federal grants and $15,000,000 of State aid will be available during the year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--Demands for the immediate ending of selective draft inductions arose in the Senate today as War Department records were quoted as "proof" that the voluntary enlistment and re-enlistment program that Congress voted last summer was "a success."
HERE are two books* that complement each other in a way their publisher probably never intended. Either one is complete in itself, but together they span the time of man on this strange planet.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--President Truman's Labor-Management Conference, which opened here on Nov. 5, ended deliberations this evening with disagreement upon the issues handled by three of the six committees, but with general expressions that the session had advanced as far as could have been accomplished under the circumstances, and with the expressed hope that another conference might add to the area of agreement reported yesterday by three committees.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--Following negotiations with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the Federal Communications Commission announced today that additional reductions in interstate telephone rates, estimated to save users over $20,000,000 a year, would become effective Feb. 1.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30.--T. Morris Perot Jr., president for the last forty years of the Perot Malting Company, established in 1687 and reputedly the oldest business concern in the United States, died yesterday in his home in the Chestnut Hill section. His age was 73.
TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 30--The Russians began carrying out a surprise evacuation of Teheran last night.
Lieut. John Freeman Forsyth, 24-year-old flying ace from Rochester, yesterday described the exploits that won him three high Navy awards as a "matter of luck."

MOSCOW, Nov. 30--Premier Stalin's prolonged and unexplained absence from Moscow has not provoked so much daily interest as might be expected. Moscovites are accustomed to what foreigners regard as portentous silences about the private affairs of political bigwigs.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 30-- There is every reason to believe that Finland's request for a $150,000,000 loan or credit from the United States will not be granted. The probability appeared today that if part of this sum is lent it will be carefully tied down to use for limited purposes.

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 30 (AP) --Henry J. Kaiser said today that he had wiped out the $28,000,000 Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan on his Permanente, Calif., magnesium plant and allied plants and was ready to expand their peacetime operations.

DETROIT, Nov. 30--The General Motors Corporation offered today to operate its parts and accessory divisions for the exclusive benefit of its competitors if the striking United Automobile Workers, CIO, would supply the labor.
At Town Hall last night, Alexander Schneider and Ralph Kirkpatrick presented a program of five sonatas for violin and harpsichord to an audience that began enthusiastic and ended shouting bravos.

LONDON, Nov. 30 (U.P.)--Young King Peter II of Yugoslavia told his Advisory Council today that he intended to write a book disclosing his relations with Marshal Tito, dominant figure of the newly proclaimed Yugoslav Republic.

Lord Riverdale, one of Britain's key industrialists and leading steel men, declared here yesterday that British financial interests favored permitting existing German industry--steel in particular--to resume limited operations.

The improvement of living conditions on the farms of the nation is a major post-war problem.

Labor shortages and work stoppages have succeeded scarcity of essential materials as the chief deterrent to industry's rapid reconversion to peacetime production, John D. Mayor-elect William O'Dwyer will leave tonight from La Guardia Field for a two-week vacation in El Centro, Calif., at his brother Frank's ranch. The trip is being made on the suggestion of his personal physician.

Fine brandy in the cask is plentiful in France, but it will take a year before exports to this country get back "more or less" to normal, Christian Braastad, managing director of Courvoisier, Ltd., of Jarnac, France, declared here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--Developments suggesting a relaxation of newsprint controls sooner than had recently been expected, although not in the near future, appeared today as the Civilian Production Administration disclosed that shipments of Canadian pulpwood into the United States in 1946 would at least equal, and perhaps exceed, those for this year.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 30-- Asserting that secure international peace could be attained only through world government and that science can make important contributions in this direction, Prof. L. A. Dubridge of the University of Rochester, director of the M.I.T. Radiation Laboratories, tonight called on the country's scientists to do their utmost to keep science strong and free.

ALBANY, Nov. 30--The State Banking Department announced today in its weekly bulletin that certified copies of Supreme Court orders dissolving the Bay Shore Savings and Loan Association of Bay Shore, L.I., and the Lawyers Credit Union of Erie County had been filed in the department, thus ending their corporate existences.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov, 30 (AP)--Rejection of "an attitude of abject terror" toward the atomic bomb and consideration, instead, of how it can be controlled was advocated today by the Yale University Institute of International Studies.

NUREMBERG, Nov. 30--There is no drearier ruin in Germany than Nuremberg. The arch criminals of the war are being tried at the scene of their crime in the sense that this place presents typical evidence of the results of the conspiracy Justice Jackson and his fellow jurists are engaged in proving.

A group of 191 leaders in many walks of life including Mayor La Guardia and Mayor-Elect William O'Dwyer, signed a statement yesterday endorsing President Truman's message to Congress proposing a national health program.

Because she is expected to die, "perhaps within six months" if she does not undergo an operation for a rare heart ailment, 2-year-old Judy Hackman flew 2,736 miles yesterday from Seattle, Wash., to Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, for an examination tomorrow by Dr. Helen B. Taussig, director of the heart clinic at the university.

PARIS, Dec. 3--The outstanding feature of the law published officially today for the nationalization of the Bank of France and four other private banks, effective on Jan. 1, is the extensive authority granted to the National Council of Credit in directing policy in the future French economy.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 3-- A funeral service for Charles Frederic Hart of Scarsdale, mechanical superintendent of THE NEW YORK TIMES from 1914 until his retirement in 1940, was held today in the chapel of the near-by Ferncliff Mausoleum. Mr. Hart died on Saturday in his home at the age of 77.
