With pre-Christmas supplies of sugar so low that many housewives were reported buying halfpound packages at black market prices, the Office of Price Administration acted yesterday against fifteen dealers who are alleged to have sold 400,000 pounds in recent months in violation of rationing regulations.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3--They Middle West Corporation sought today from the Securities and Exchange Commission permission to sell from time to time on exchanges, over the counter or privately all or part of Middle West's holdings of common stock of the Midland Realization Company without a registration statement being in effect.

The War Department has turned down Mayor La Guardia's request for the immediate mass release of New York policemen still in the Army on the ground that such special group releases "would compel favorable action in other equally meritorious cases," the Mayor disclosed at City Hall yesterday.

At the request of the New York State Board of Regents, the Board of Education will submit today a voluminous reply to charges that conditions in the city schools are "chaotic" and will emphasize that its inability to recruit skilled teachers and a general lack of funds are the principal problems faced in operating the 801 units of the system.

The Federal grand jury impaneled to investigate the nation-wide black market in textiles and allied industries began its inquiry yesterday afternoon, and several witnesses were questioned before it by Irving H. Saypol, chief assistant United States attorney.

Tom Smith, trainer of the nation's most successful 1945 racing stable, is to appear before a joint session of the State Racing Commission and the Jockey Club today to plead for remission of his oneyear suspension on the charge that one of his animals was stimulated.

The expenditures in Palestine of the Jewish National Fund, the Jewish Agency and the Palestine Foundation Fund totaled $31,104,146 in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, four times the figure spent in 1940-41, it was reported yesterday by Rabbi James G. Heller, chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, through which the three organizations derive their American support.

ALBANY, Dec. 13--The twentytwo-month extraordinary grand jury investigation of the Legislature, which resulted in one indictment, three presentments, two citations for contempt, and no convictions, ended today. The jury, ordered by Governor Dewey, has disbanded at its own request.

Conditions in the real estate market, especially in the metropolitan area, are ripe for inflation, Elliott V. Bell, State Superintendent of Banks warned yesterday at a meeting of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations at the Waldorf-Astoria.

PEIPING, China, Dec. 13--Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, making his first trip to what formerly was Japanese-occupied territory without the slightest trace of triumphal fanfare, is visiting Peiping, it was learned today.

Prices of vegetables and fruits, except those italicized, result from a spot check of independent and chain stores in leading shopping centers of the city, and are reported by the Department of Markets.

War Mobilization Director Snyder has announced a three-point program to meet the critical housing shortage. He proposes, first, that Army and Navy barracks and dormitories be converted, so as to make them available immediately to house the families of returning veterans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13--The Army Pearl Harbor Board statement that the Navy received on Dec. 3, 1941, an intercepted Japanese message saying Japan intended to go to war with the United States, was challenged in a summary of all Navy investigations submitted late today to the Congressional committee inquiring into the disaster.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 13--The Right Rev. Cameron J. Davis resigned today as Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Western New York, effective at the general convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church in September.

After a thorough tryout in the Central Pacific, Maurice Evans' latest interpretation of "Hamlet" arrived last evening at the newly named Columbus Circle Theatre. This is the so-called "GI version," and it is an interesting and a good one.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 13 (AP)--Job Dean Jessop, who had arrived at Gulfstream Park from Hot Springs yesterday boasting 278 winners to lead all jockeys this year, got into action today with three mounts--winning with his second and barely losing with his third in the Lee Purse.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13--The railroads put in the hands of the Government today their controversy with twenty unions over the latters' demands for wage increases and changes in working rules. They estimate that the unions' demands would add $2,000,000,000 annually to railroad costs. About 1,200,000 workers are involved in the case.

DETROIT, Dec. 13--Nearly 300 Detroit automobile and advertising executives, as guests of THE NEW YORK TIMES, heard a discussion today of industry-Government relations and veterans rehabilitation problems by members of THE TIMES staff. WASHINGTON, Dec. 13--During the week ended Dec. 12, member bank reserve balances decreased $573,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 13-- Miss Anna Chapin Ray, author of stories for children, died here today at the age of 80. She suffered a fracture of the hip in October and had been in St. Raphael's Hospital until reecntly when she moved to a convalescent home.

Dwight D. Eisenhower, Chief of Staff.

Insulin is secreted by the pancreas or sweetbread. If the pancreas fails to produce enough the body cannot burn up sugar. Result: diabetes. Because their sweetbreads are defective diabetics must either reduce their consumption of sugar and starches (converted into the sugar by the body) or inject insulin into themselves with a syringe. These crude facts have been known for years. But the process of sugar utilization remained much of a mystery.

MOSCOW, Dec. 18--Although definite information about the progress of the conference of Foreign Ministers of the United States, the Soviet Union and Britain is almost entirely lacking, it can be reported today, for what it is worth, that the mood is earnest on all sides.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18--A marked coolness was shown by President Roosevelt at the Atlantic Charter Conference to any immediate post-war creation of a new Assembly of the League of Nations, and he favored first allowing an Anglo-American international police force to function, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18--The Senate passed late today by a voice vote a bill to dispose of about 4,750 surplus war cargo ships totaling nearly 50,000,000 deadweight tons and costing an estimated $10,000,000,000.

LONDON, Dec. 18--A reluctant House of Lords ratified today the financial accord with the United States by ninety votes to eight, with about one hundred Conservative peers abstaining and some 600 absent. Immediately afterward the Bretton Woods agreement was also passed.

The annual report of the Cudahy Packing Company covering the fiscal year ended on Oct. 27 disclosed yesterday a net income of $2,505,097 after taxes and all charges, equal to $4.12 a share of common stock. In the preceding fiscal year the company had a net of $3,190,061, or $5.58 a common share.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18--In a ten-page ruling a special threejudge Federal expediting court unanimously approved late today the decision of Pullman, Inc., to sell its sleeping-car subsidiary, the Pullman Company, to a group of fifty-two railroads for $75,000,000.

Establishment of a medical school at the Hebrew University in Palestine will complete a circle by which medical lore came to North America and will return progress to an area that was a cradle of medical science, Dr. Charles Gordon Heyd, past president of the American Medical Association, declared last night in an address at the Hotel Pierre.
